http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/4262336.stm 
 
 This really doesn't sit right with me, if these soldiers where arrested for a criminal act then we should have respected Iraqi Law. Instead we knocked down a jail to rescue these guys. This gives out the impression that we are the rulers and Iraqi Laws are subservient to the occupational forces.
 
 I will be watching this with interest, to see how we justify those actions.

This little snippet at the bottom botehrs me almost as much:
 
 
The Iraqi government says a nephew of Saddam Hussein, Ayman Sabawi, has been sentenced to life in prison for funding Iraq's insurgency

 
 Without a constitutional government in place, how did they manage to hold a trial for somebody? If he has already been sentenced, that would seem to suggest that he wa tried by our puppet government.

This really doesn't sit right with me, if these soldiers where arrested for a criminal act then we should have respected Iraqi Law. Instead we knocked down a jail to rescue these guys. This gives out the impression that we are the rulers and Iraqi Laws are subservient to the occupational forces.

 Erm, the occupational forces are the rulers of Iraq and the Iraqi government should just do as they are told, that's what they get payed for.
 
 
Without a constitutional government in place, how did they manage to hold a trial for somebody? If he has already been sentenced, that would seem to suggest that he wa tried by our puppet government.

 Well, this really was to be expected anyway. Since the start of the war the Iraqi and American forces have taken over 15.000 prisoners. I'm willing to bet that the vast majority of those prisoners are Sunnis who aren't insurgents but just innocent victims of the tribal war.

Well, this really was to be expected anyway. Since the start of the war the Iraqi and American forces have taken over 15.000 prisoners. I'm willing to bet that the vast majority of those prisoners are Sunnis who aren't insurgents but just innocent victims of the tribal war.

 
 
 I am not surprised at the news, just a little dismayed. We are supposed to be the good guys, and here we are advocating the trial and imprisonment of people without the benifit of a constitutional government, and the American public is not throwing its hands up in outrage. Not surprising I suppose, givent he apathetic ignorance that Americans seem to prefer living under, but diheartening none the less,.

Yes it's certainly disheartening, but I have no illusions anymore about justice prevailing in both Iraq or the US. 
 Ever since the Supreme Court took away the civil rights of Jose Padilla and basically nullified the 5th Amendment, a signal was given that governments in Iraq and the US can just imprison anyone they want.
 In that respect it's the Saddam era all over again, only the names of the puppets have changed.
